div1.ab: IN THE DISTRICT Circuit COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, IN AND FOR THE Ninth Circuit DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of Lee Fong for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
div1.p: In this case, Lee Fong is charged with having violated Section 6 of Ordinance No. 710 of the City of Seattle, entitled "An ordinance regulating the establishment and maintenance of public laundries and public wash-houses within the limites of the City of Seattle," Sections 2, 3 and 6 of said ordinance reasing as follows:

"Sec.2. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to conduct or maintain a public laundry or washhouse within the city of Seattle without having first obtained a certificate signed by the health officer of the City of Seattle that the premises are properly and sufficiently drained and that all proper arrangements for carrying on the business without injury to the sanitary condition of the neighborhood have been complied with, also a certificate signed by the chief of the fire department of the City of Seattle that the stoves, washing and drying apparatus and the applicances for heating smoothing irons are in good condition, and that their use is not dangerous to the surrounding property from fire, and that all proper precautions have been taken to comply with the provisions of the ordinances of the city then in force making regulations concerning the erection and use of buildings and for the protection of property
from injury or destruction by fire.

"Sec.3. It shall be the duty of the health officer, also of the chief of the fire department, respectively, upon application from any person or persons proposing to open or conduct the business of a public laundry within the City of Seattle to inspect the premises in which it is proposed to carry on said business, or in which said business is being carried on, with a view to ascertain whether the said premises are provided with proper drainage and sanitary appliances, also whether the provisions of the ordinances of the city then in force making regulations concerning the erection and use of building and for the protection of property from injury or destruction by fire, have been complied with, and if found in all respects satisfactory, then to issue to such person or persons the certificates provided for in section 2 of this ordinance. No charge whatever shall be made or compensation or fee collected or received for the performance of any of the services required by the provisions of this ordinance in the inspection of premises or the issuance of a certificate, but all such services shall be performed free of charge."

"Sec. 6. It shall be unlawful, from and after the passage of this ordinance, for any person or persons to establish, maintain or carry on a laundry within the corporate limits of the City of Seattle, without having first obtained the consent of the common council, except the same be located in a building constructed either of brick or stone and covered with a metal roof."
And The complaint upon which the defendant is held is based upon Section 6 of said ordinances, the charges part of which reads as follows:

"Then and there being the said defendant, Lee Fong, did wilfully and unlawfully, at Number 1410 Fir Street,in said City of Seattle, establish, maintain and carry on a laundry within the corporate limits of the said City of Seattle and at said place, without first obtaining the consent of the City Council of said City, the said laundry not being located in a building constructed either of brick, stone, nor covered with a metal roof."

Our position in this matter is, that these sections should be, and necessarily are, construed together, and that, when so construed and understood, this case is taken entirely out of the question of arbitrary power as laid down in the case of Yick Wo v. Hopkins 118 U.S. 356. The City Council, after investigating the reports of the Chief of the Fire Department and the Health Officers, will, in all cases, grant a permit to conduct a laundry if the reports are correct, and if the conduct of the laundry under all the circumstances is not dangerous to the public health or to surrounding property. This is not a mere arbitrary power, but the Council takes its recommendation from the Chief of the Fire Department and the Health Officer and uses in a discretionary power as to granting the permit, rather than an arbitrary power referred to in the case above. "Regulations respecting the pursuit of lawful trades and businesses are of very frequent occurrence in the various cities of the country, and what such regulations shall be, and to what particular trade, business, or occupation they shall apply, are questions for the State to determine, and their determination comes within the proper exercise of the police power of the State, and unless the regulations are so utterly

unreasonable and extravagant in their nature and purpose that the property and personal rights of the citizen are unnecessarily, and in a manner wholly arbitrary, interfered with or destroyed without due process of law, they do not extend beyond the power of the State to pass, and they form no subject for Federal interference." This rules is laid down and promulgated in the case of Harry Gundling vs. The City of Chicago 177 U.S. Page 633. This is a case relating to persons selling cigarettes. A portion of Section 1 of the ordinance of Chicago reads as follows:

"Any person, firm or corporation desiring a license to sell cigarettes shall make written application for that purpose to the commissioner of health, in which shall be described the location at which such sales are proposed to be made. Said application shall be accompanied by evidence that the applicant, if a single individual, all the members of the firms, if a copartnership, and person or persons in charge of the business, if a corporation, is or are persons of good character and reputation. The commissioner of health shall thereupon submit to the mayor the said application with the evidence aforesaid, with his opinion as to the propriety of granting such license, and if the mayor shall be satisifed that the persons before mentioned are of good character and reputation, and are suitable persons to be intrusted with the sale of cigarettes, he shall issue a license in accordance with such application."

The ordinance in the case at bar does not grant to the City Council of the City of Seattle any more arbitrary power than is granted in this ordinance, when our ordinance is properly construed with Sections 2 and 3. In the Chicago case, the Court said that "the ordinance in question here

does not grant to the mayor arbitrary power such as is described in the above-mentioned laundry case, but the provisions is similar to that mentioned in the foregoing extract from the opinion in that case. In the case at bar, the license is to be issued if the mayor is satisified that the person applying is of good character and reputation and a suitable person to be intrusted with the sale of cigarettes."
In this case at bar, the permit is to be granted if the City Council finds that all suitable arrangements have been made for conducting a laundry, but not otherwise.

While this is not the language of Section 6 under which the defendant is being prosecuted, it is the clear and evident intention when the ordinance is construed as a whole. We see, in the first place, that a permit must be had from the Chief of the Fire Department as well as the Health Officer of the City, in all cases, but this is not sufficient in cases where laundries are to be erected and operated in buildings not of brick or stone nor metal roofs. In all other these cases, the certificates must be had, and as well as the certificates, a permite form the City Council. Should the buildings not of brick or stone nor covered with metal roofs be found to be suitable and comply with all the ordinances of the City and proper permits granted by the Chief of the Fire Department and the Health Officer, there would be little discretion left for the City Council, and should the Council act in an arbitrary manner after these permits were granted, the Courts would not uphold their action. There is no question of the right of municipalities to pass ordinances to control businesses of this character in looking to the protection of property and persons.

The Statute of Washington, as found in Subdivision 22 of Section 739 of 1 Ballinger's Code, in relation to powers of cities of the first class concerning the construction of buildings and the regulation and management of occupations carried on therein, reads as follows:

"22. To direct the location and construction of all builings in which any trade or occupation offensive to the senses or deleterious to public health or safety shall be carried on, and to regulate the management thereof; and to prohibit the erection or maintenance of such buildings or structures, or the carrying on of such trades or occupation within the limits of such corporation, or within the distance of two miles beyond the boundaries thereof."
We contend that, under this statute, the City of Seattle has full power and authority to enact and enforce such ordinance as the one in issue in the case at bar.

While there are certain questions of fact in the petition of Lee Fong for the writ of habeas corpus, all matters and things of that character have been by agreement eliminated, and this matter is submitted strictly and only upon the constitutionality of the ordinance under which the said Lee Fong is being prosecuted. It is our contention that this ordinance goes no farther and attempts to do nothing more than the one in the Chicago case relating to the sale of cigarettes, and we insist, that the ordinance is valid.
